Question: Q. What is the scientific method?
Option A: A) A systematic approach to conducting research
Option B: B) A method for measuring distance
Option C: C) A type of laboratory equipment
Option D: D) A type of statistical analysis

Question: Q. What is the purpose of a literature review in research?
Option A: A) To summarize existing research on a topic
Option B: B) To collect primary data

Question: Q. What is the difference between qualitative and quantitative research?
Option A: A) Qualitative research focuses on words and meanings, while quantitative research focuses on numbers and statistics
Option B: B) Qualitative research is more reliable than quantitative research
Option C: C) Quantitative research is used only in social sciences
Option D: D) There is no difference between qualitative and quantitative research

Question: Q. What is an independent variable in an experiment?
Option A: A) The variable that is measured or observed
Option B: B) The variable that is manipulated or changed
Option C: C) The variable that remains constant
Option D: D) The variable that is controlled by the researcher

Question: Q. What is a hypothesis in research?
Option A: A) An educated guess or prediction about the outcome of an experiment
Option B: B) A summary of existing research

Question: Q. What is the purpose of a control group in an experiment?
Option A: A) To provide a basis for comparison
Option B: B) To manipulate the independent variable

Question: Q. What is the difference between correlation and causation?
Option A: A) Correlation refers to a relationship between two variables, while causation implies that one variable causes the other
Option B: B) Correlation and causation are the same thing
Option C: C) Correlation is not used in research
Option D: D) Causation is only used in qualitative research

Question: Q. What is a dependent variable in an experiment?
Option A: A) The variable that is manipulated or changed
Option B: B) The variable that remains constant
Option C: C) The variable that is measured or observed
Option D: D) The variable that is controlled by the researcher

Question: Q. What is a research question?
Option A: A) A statement of what the researcher intends to investigate
Option B: B) A hypothesis

Question: Q. What is the purpose of random sampling in research?
Option A: A) To select participants from a specific population
Option B: B) To ensure every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected

Question: Q. What is the difference between primary and secondary research?
Option A: A) Primary research involves collecting original data, while secondary research involves analyzing existing data
Option B: B) Primary research is less reliable than secondary research
Option C: C) Secondary research is conducted in a laboratory setting
Option D: D) There is no difference between primary and secondary research

Question: Q. What is the purpose of peer review in research?
Option A: A) To ensure the quality and validity of research findings
Option B: B) To collect data

Question: Q. What is a research proposal?
Option A: A) A document that outlines the research project and its objectives
Option B: B) A hypothesis

Question: Q. What is the difference between cross-sectional and longitudinal research?
Option A: A) Cross-sectional research collects data at a single point in time, while longitudinal research collects data over a period of time
Option B: B) Cross-sectional research is more reliable than longitudinal research
Option C: C) Longitudinal research is used only in qualitative research
Option D: D) There is no difference between cross-sectional and longitudinal research

Question: Q. What is the purpose of statistical analysis in research?
Option A: A) To summarize and interpret data
Option B: B) To collect data

Question: Q. What is the difference between qualitative data and quantitative data?
Option A: A) Qualitative data is descriptive, while quantitative data is numerical
Option B: B) Qualitative data is more reliable than quantitative data
Option C: C) Quantitative data is collected through observation
Option D: D) There is no difference between qualitative and quantitative data

Question: Q. What is a case study in research?
Option A: A) An in-depth analysis of a single individual, group, or event
Option B: B) A literature review

Question: Q. What is the purpose of informed consent in research involving human participants?
Option A: A) To ensure that participants are fully informed about the study and voluntarily agree to participate
Option B: B) To manipulate variables

Question: Q. What is the difference between validity and reliability in research?
Option A: A) Validity refers to the accuracy of a measurement, while reliability refers to the consistency of a measurement
Option B: B) Validity and reliability are the same thing
Option C: C) Validity is only used in qualitative research
Option D: D) Reliability is more important than validity

Question: Q. What is a research design?
Option A: A) The overall plan for conducting a research study
Option B: B) A hypothesis

Question: Q. What is the purpose of a double-blind study in research?
Option A: A) To ensure that neither the participants nor the researchers know which group is receiving the treatment
Option B: B) To manipulate variables

Question: Q. What is the difference between an experimental group and a control group in an experiment?
Option A: A) The experimental group receives the treatment or intervention, while the control group does not
Option B: B) The control group receives the treatment or intervention, while the experimental group does not
Option C: C) There is no difference between an experimental group and a control group
Option D: D) Both groups receive the same treatment

Question: Q. What is the purpose of a research ethics committee?
Option A: A) To review research proposals involving human participants and ensure ethical standards are met
Option B: B) To manipulate variables

Question: Q. What is the difference between deductive and inductive reasoning in research?
Option A: A) Deductive reasoning starts with a general theory or hypothesis and tests it with specific observations, while inductive reasoning starts with specific observations and develops a general theory or hypothesis
Option B: B) Deductive reasoning is more reliable than inductive reasoning
Option C: C) Inductive reasoning is only used in qualitative research
Option D: D) There is no difference between deductive and inductive reasoning

Question: Q. What is the purpose of an abstract in a research paper?
Option A: A) To summarize the key findings of the study
Option B: B) To manipulate variables

Question: Q. What is the difference between a research objective and a research question?
Option A: A) A research objective is a statement of what the researcher intends to achieve, while a research question is a specific inquiry about a topic
Option B: B) A research objective is more general than a research question
Option C: C) A research question is only used in qualitative research
Option D: D) There is no difference between a research objective and a research question

Question: Q. What is the purpose of triangulation in research?
Option A: A) To increase the validity and reliability of findings by using multiple methods or sources of data
Option B: B) To manipulate variables

Question: Q. What is the difference between internal validity and external validity in research?
Option A: A) Internal validity refers to the extent to which the results of a study can be attributed to the independent variable, while external validity refers to the generalizability of the results to other populations or settings
Option B: B) Internal validity is more important than external validity
Option C: C) External validity is only used in qualitative research
Option D: D) There is no difference between internal validity and external validity
